description: From Middle French stupide, from Latin stupidus (“struck senseless, amazed”), from stupeō (“be amazed or confounded, be struck senseless”), from Proto-Indo-European *(s)tup-, *(s)tewp- (“to wonder”), from Proto-Indo-European *(s)tew- (“to stand, stay”). Cognate with Old High German stubarōn (“to be astonished, be stunned, be blocked”). Related also to Old English stoppian (“to block, stop”). See stop.

adjectives.description: stupid (comparative stupider or more stupid, superlative stupidest or most stupid)

entries.meaning: Lacking in intelligence or exhibiting the quality of having been done by someone lacking in intelligence.
examples: It got trapped in the fishing net because it's a big stupid jellyfish!

entries.meaning: (archaic) Characterized by or in a state of stupor; paralysed.
examples: No sigh to rise, no tear had pow'r to flow, Fix'd in a stupid lethargy of woe.

entries.meaning: (archaic) Lacking sensation; inanimate; destitute of consciousness; insensate.
examples: Were it not for [fire], the whole wou'd be one great stupid inanimate mass.

entries.meaning: Dulled in feeling or sensation; torpid.

examples: That dunk was stupid! His head was above the rim!

entries.meaning: (slang, euphemistic)   Replaces an obscene or profane word.
examples: Dewey: "It's too narrow for all three of us. Oh, bummer!"
Huey: "Or we could just go single file."

adverbs.description: stupid (comparative more stupid, superlative most stupid)

examples: "What a stupid I am!" Harry exclaimed, as she watched the man ride away in the distance.

entries.meaning: (colloquial, uncountable) The condition or state of being stupid; stupidity, stupidness.
